title: My wife received a phone call to appear in court tomorrow for a debt she can prove she dosnt owe.What do we do
question: My wife never received a summons but got a phone call saying she has to go to court one day later.The company says she recieved a payday advance she never got and we can prove it.What is also weird they said they are going to pick her up for court.This has already happend once before but we were able to prove she never recieved money over the phone.This new company wont do the same thing.What is our next step this seems weird.
answers:
It appears that they must have filed a lawsuit against her and perhaps even now have a default judgment. If you go to my Avvo profile, I have written several legal guides to help, including one that discusses how to get court case information on line in many California Superior Courts, so you can find out a little more on this case. Trying to call the clerk can be a waste of time, as it is difficult to reach busy courts to find out about a specific case.

The pickup for court makes me think that she may be required to appear to answer in court questions and bring certain documents related to her assets for a judgment debtor examination. She should have been served with the notice to appear for this examination.

One final thought: the payday lender or its debt collection agency may be harassing you. In the abundance of caution, find out from the court if there are any cases pending or filed against her and the status. Below is a link to my web site which has on the page linked below PDF's of many of the court filings used in debt collection lawsuits, so you can see if you recognize any.

If a default judgment was entered, she should hire an attorney to help set that aside, if not served properly. If need be, please contact me.

She should call the court to find out whether this is real or is a scam. If it is real, show up to court (do not let a creditor take you) and tell the judge that you were not served and that you dispute the entire case. If there is no case, then contact a consumer law attorney about possible violations of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act and California state law.

[I am a Virginia attorney. This communication is intended as general information and not specific legal advice, and this communication does not create an attorney-client relationship.]

In Sacramento you can get some of this information on line. It is strange that someone would call on a law suit - they would normally prefer you not answer or show up and then get a default judgment. There are some agencies that will claim that they served you and never did.
